ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY ACTION POLICIES

The Aspen Distribution facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (RAP) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the Aspen Distribution's PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

Aspen Distribution maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.

Aspen Distribution has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, Victorville Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Aspen Distribution to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Aspen Distribution began operation of the facility upon its completion in December 2001.  The ammonia system at Aspen Distribution consists primarily of vessels, compressors, condensers, evaporators and associated piping.  The majority of the equipment is located inside the engine room.  The system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator.  There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.

The Aspen Distribution facility provides cold storage space and a docking area for candy items.  Ammonia sensors are located in the engine room, cold storage and dock areas that alert facility personn

el and activate the ventilation system in the engine room and close all feed lines out of the engine room.  The ammonia detection system also has the capability to shut-off all electrical power to the engine room to eliminate the potential for an explosion.

The maximum intended inventory of ammonia is 20,000 pounds.


HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary

Scenario Description : Release of the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in a vessel (the Controlled Pressure Receiver has the capacity to hold a much higher quantity than the ammonia charge of 20,000 pounds) - 20,000 pounds in 10 minutes.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F stability.  Since the CPR vessel is located inside, the enclosure of the building was considered a passive mitigation measure, reducing the effective release rate to the outside atmosphere by 55%.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches 1.5 miles off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

Alternative Release Result Summary

Scenario Description : The alternative release scenario presented is similar to the worst case in that it is a liquid release.  The alternative release scenario chosen for this facility is that of a 0.25 inch diameter orifice leading to an airborne release, representative of a pump seal leak, a gasket rupture, pinhole leak due to corrosion, flange seal leak, valve bonnet seal leak, etc.  It is assumed that this release is from the high side of the system; therefore at a maximum pressure of 180 psig.  The release scenario is assumed to last one hour, thereby incorporating mitigation measures such as the ammonia sensors and system shutdown.

EPA allows a facility to use typical meteorological cond

itions at the facility. For this scenario, a wind speed of 3 meters/second and neutral conditions, D stability, were used to find the distance the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in an urban area.

EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities, Exhibit 4-5 for D Stability, Wind Speed 3.0 Meters per Second, was used to find the downwind distance for the alternate release scenario. This release reaches 0.1 miles off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Aspen Distribution ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program. 

Ammonia detectors are strategically located in the engine room and evaporator warehouses.  In case of ammonia detection, visible and audible alarms will activate at the facility and at the off-site monitoring company.

In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, evaporator fans shut-down, etc.).  In the case of a power failure, a back-up generator with a minimum of two operating hours shall power the refrigeration control system, equipment room purge fan, evaporative condenser fan and water pump.

The system also incorporates a pressure relief line.  In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent through pressure relief valves to a common header which relieves to an outside water diffusion tank until the system pressure decreases sufficiently to reseat the valves.  This mechanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized.

Ammo

nia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.

In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Because this is a new ammonia refrigeration system, there have been no accidental ammonia releases at the Aspen Distribution facility within the last five years. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Aspen Distribution has an emergency action plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Action Plan (RMP) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the City of Victorville Fire Department and the local fire houses.  In case of a major ammonia emergency, the facility will first call 9-1-1 to alert the local Police and Fire Departments.  Other responders will be called as needed, including the City of Victorville Fire Department Hazardous Materials Division.  If a release exceeds the federal reporting quantity of 100 pounds for ammonia, the National Response Center will be called.

Aspen Distribution maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The plan is reviewed and updated

at least once per year.  This plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to renovation of the facility.

Aspen Distribution will be responsible for evacuating and ensuring the safety of its employees and will coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted in two stages.  This document includes the results from the two elements: 1) the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study conducted October 24, 2001, and 2) a Facility Inspection conducted December 17, 2001. These studies were performed to define potential hazards associated with operational deviations of the ammonia system.

The Seismic Assessment performed on December 17, 2001, by a licensed structural engineer, also generated mitigation measures to improve the seismic adequacy of the refrigeration system and the building itself.  All recommendations are scheduled to be completed by December 2, 2002.

Process Hazard Analysis

R01 Establish a training policy so that every employee at the facility has the following information: general ammonia awareness, what to do when an ammonia leak is observed, where to go when an evacuation is called for.

R02 Establish an emergency action plan that includes facility personnel responsibilities during an evacuation.

R03 Establish a preventive maintenance procedure to test and calibrate the ammonia sensors at the facility based on the manufacturer's recommendations.

R04 Determine and implement methods for alerting all on-site personnel (including truck drivers) of an emergency situation that requires an evacuation.

R05 Establish a policy to ensure that extraneous materials, especially flammables, are not stored in the engine room.

R06 Ensure that all the pressure relief valves in the system are replaced or recertified at least every 5 years or any time on

e engages to vent pressure.

R07 Ensure that the temperature of the water from the eye wash / safety shower station outside the engine room is regulated (i.e. insulated or recirculated).

R08 Coordinate emergency response efforts with the local emergency responders (i.e. fire department) on a periodic and ongoing basis.

R09 Ensure that oil draining procedures are documented and that they agree with the procedures used by the refrigeration maintenance contractor.

R10 Establish a procedure for an Aspen employee to complete a daily log sheet to record typical system parameters in the engine room.

R11 Determine where the liquid drains in the engine room terminate.  Ensure that the 
facility evacuation location is not located near drain vents.

R12 Ensure that the high level cutout float switch on the Suction Accumulator is tested annually.

R13 Determine if the system is designed to require manual restart following a high level cutout or if the system will automatically restart.

R14 Ensure that all of the evaporators are cleaned (i.e. pressure washed) as needed to maintain efficiency.

R15 Establish a policy to prevent damaging the evaporator drain pans or piping (i.e. liquid float drainer) during maintenance activities with a man lift.

R16 Include the compressor manufacturer's recommendations in the preventive maintenance program.

R17 Consider requiring the refrigeration maintenance contractor to check in with Aspen prior to performing maintenance or repairs on the roof or in other isolated locations.

R18 Ensure that the Condensers are maintained including a regular water treatment program and a periodic cleaning of the water reservoir.

R19 Include a periodic test of the emergency water pump associated with the water diffusion tank in the maintenance program.

R20 Ensure that ammonia warning placards are placed outside engine room door.

R21 Ensure that there is an ammonia stop button outside the engine room door.  Train the ¿daily walkthrough' employee in its

use.

R22 Ensure all refrigeration lines are properly labeled. 

R23 Ensure oil pot drain lines have a spring loaded release valve installed.

R24 Ensure that a wind-sock is placed on top the guard shack at the front of the property.

R25 Consider installing a hand or electric winch on the roof to aid maintenance workers in their operations.

Seismic Assessment

S01: Anchor bolt all equipment in the Engine Room.

S02: Provide lateral bracing for overhead piping in Engine Room;
  a) TSS, TSR, HTRS and HGD Compressor lines to Engine Room roof or wall.
  b) HTRL, HTRS and HGD pipelines at bottom of vertical run to/through roof.

S03: Provide longitudinal bracing to Engine Room roof for Thermosyphon Receiver and associated piping.

S04: Provide lateral and longitudinal bracing for Pipeways (HTRL, HTRS and HGD) on roof.
 a) Install missing Pipeway supports.
 b) Install at an appropriate spacing lateral bracing (i.e. parallel to the pipelines) of selected Pipeway supports.
 c) Provide  -bolt attachment of HTRL, HTRS and HGD pipelines to Pipeway supports.
 d) Provide  -bolt attachment of HTRL, HTRS and HGD pipelines at first Pipeway support after penetration of roof.

Before the system is filled with ammonia the following items should be completed: 1, 2a, 2b, 3 and 4d.
